Very interesting, kemie. I'm right here in Sweden and if I got off my butt and learned Swedish I would have already read this news.

Caps at the beginning of sentences have the functionality of marking when once sentence ends, and another begins. In 'chatting' people generally do one or two sentences at a time, so the differentiation is already marked by the exchange, and caps don't help further. But in continuious text like this, they are very functional. You could do away with this use of caps by adding extra space between sentences, but this would not save space, as the Swedish official wanted to.   
   
In capitalizing proper names, you give the readers the signal that if the name is not important to them, they don't have to slow down to read it. So it is functional too.   
   
I don't know whether the noun caps in German are a benefit in German and what their impact on English would be.   
   
How to capitalize titles is also currently in flux, and I could see this changing, as it is not really an issue of functionality.   
   
I was interested to read in one of Giampa's links on the 'Bauhaus' thread that they were opposed to caps, as well as serifs.   
   
To a great extent their ideas have been tested over time. Sans serifs have succeeded in titles and display, but not in small solid text. And caps have not been abandoned. I personally think that this is not conservatism, but that the scribes who evolved these conventions - like the lower case letters themselves - were on to what is really functional.   
   
I think that those who don't use caps in continuous text either don't understand their functionality, or can't be bothered to hit the shift key to help their reader.

PS the use of san serifs on the internet for continuous text is I think a compromise because of low res. And I think everyone recognizes reading long text on lo-res screens is a chore compared to high resolution printing, with serifs.
How Bauhaus...
\> The director of J
I have a better idea, rather than setting everything lowercase, why not set all government documents in Agenda Thin Ultra Condensed and have alot of minus tracking, you'd save tons of paper.

Hrant: _Thompson did his stuff because of his son's condition._   
   
What condition is that, other than being a new reader?   
According to [Martin Spector's article](http://web.archive.org/web/20090627135833/http:/www.pbtweb.com/alpha26/commentary.html), Thompson noticed   
his son had trouble with his first text because many capitol   
letters have completely different forms from their lowercase   
counterparts requiring all new readers to learn more forms.   
   
But that digresses from his main point: that caps aren't   
necessary for reading comprehension.

\> What condition is that   
   
Dyslexia, no? Or some disability (not just "learning to read").   
   
However, I would agree that the UC letters which look like big versions of their lc counterparts should be reformed to diverge more. Latin is already too simple: the brain -unlike a computer- relishes much more complexity than that.   
   
That's the main problem with Thompson, Cassandre, the Bauhaus, Noordzij, Crouwel et alia: they don't get that conscious design is only tangentially relevant to what our subconscious needs.

\>main point: that caps aren't   
necessary for reading comprehension.   
   
My main point - and Hrant's and Giampa's (Hey if we three agree it must be right!) - is that caps are HELPFUL to reading comprehension. You can set text with no word spaces and no punctuation, as I believe the Romans once did, and it is perfectly legible - and very much harder to read.

_That's the main problem with Thompson, Cassandre, the Bauhaus, Noordzij, Crouwel et alia._   
   
Oh dear. Who

It never seems simple around here. And here I was thinking we were talking about saving trees. Patiently I was waiting for the obvious Bauhausian conclusion that all books should be made out of fibreglass.   
   
What make me sick is this incredible learning disability that everyone seems to have become afflicted. I can see that it is becoming contagious. Please don't sneeze in my direction!   
   
Good old fashion serifs and traditional typography has fared us well for more than five hundred years, but now, it seems to be impairing "typographers" ability to read. This ailment may require serious medication. Perhaps less vanity and a good pair of glasses.   
   
Stop deamonizing good typography. If you are having trouble learning you are just going to have to study harder. The answer is not to make bigger type, or remove capitals, or remove "humanizing serifs". The answer is that you are a slow learner, blind or, not paying attention. Or the more obvious.   
   
So go to bed drink plenty of fluids and pick up a good old fashioned reading habit. When was the last time you read Moby Dick?   
   
It is not necessarily life threatening. Good literature, unlike fire extinguishers, or poultry do not have expiry dates. Your only danger is that you may learn that caps and serifs are not going to make you grow warts.   
   
So stop believing horned rimmed morons that do not know how to put their pinky on the shift key. For instance this baboon.   
 [http://people.ucsc.edu/~gflores/bauhaus/type.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090627135833/http:/people.ucsc.edu/~gflores/bauhaus/type.html)
dON'T tRY tO eliMinAte onE caSe Out of COnveNIeNCe. ThE MoRe vAriEty tHe BeTTEr.
At least someone agrees with me.

_And since caps only take up only about 5% of text (although double to triple that in German)..._   
   
Unlike lowercase letters, the frequency of caps depends very much on the nature of the text being sampled, _e.g._ something written in the first person is likely to have a high incidence of uppercase I, while something in the third person might have few or even none. Similarly, if a document makes reference to many proper nouns -- people, places or organisations -- or uses acronyms, it will have a higher frequency of uppercase letters. When I was sampling texts for average English letter frequency, I deliberately ignored uppercase letters, because including them distorted the frequency more than excluding them.   
   
I initially thought that it would be essential to sample uppercase letters in German frequency analysis, but I was surprised by just how low the frequency of uppercase letters _compared to lowercase letters_ is even in German. Sampling the same text in English and German translation -- a Bible text of 30,000+ words, including a lot of proper nouns that bumped up the average uppercase letter count for the English --, I found that in the German the uppercase letters only accounted for 3.7% of the total alphabetic characters. I think the frequency of uppercase letters in German is often overstated.

_Good old fashion serifs and traditional typography has   
fared us well for more than five hundred years_      
   
...and the world was flat for much longer. Gerald, you're   
smart enough to know tradition isn't reason enough to keep   
doing something in the same way.   
   
Just to be clear, I'm not advocating the elimination of   
uppercase. I'm only questioning whether our dependence   
on caps is based on their empirical aid to readability or   
simply because we're used to them.

\>ThE MoRe vAriEty tHe BeTTEr.   
   
No, not the more variety the better, and not the more simplicity the better - as Bauhaus theology would have it. The degree and nature of the variety should suit the purpose. Caps help distinguish sentences from words, just as word spaces help distinguish letters from words. It is all about visual clues to structural information.
\> Who
Apparently not.

Stephen, can you agree that it helps the reader to have visual markers distinguishing words from letters (word spacing), sentences from words (period and initial cap) and paragraphs from sentences (indents, line space, etc.)?   
   
If so then the question is what works visually to separate sentences. I think that the period is too small to do it by itself. Either more space after the sentence or a cap or a bigger punctuation than the period would be needed.   
   
I can't get the sentences to have more space after a period here - something to do with the program - but try it and you will see what I mean.

\>Right, and Latin doesn't have nearly enough.   
   
Letters looking too much alike is not just a problem of the Roman alphabet. I think it is a problem in the Hebrew alphabet- which is actually the Aramaic alphabet - too. This makes me think that there is some deeper reason for it - maybe there is no ideal solution of harmony vs variety.

Stephen,   
   
_...and the world was flat for much longer. Gerald, you're smart enough to know tradition isn't reason enough to keep doing something in the same way._   
   
To Americans and Europeans the world is still flat. America was not discovered, it was invented. Columbus when he died was almost unknown. White man has never seen what they claim to have discovered because the saw only one big flat equation, gold and silver = fat men, women and children. They stole the Gold and destroyed a civilization. _1) "destruction of the old representational image in order to achieve new experiences, a new wealth of optical expression."_   
   
 **NOTE THE WORD DESTRUCTION!**

_Right, and Latin doesn't have nearly enough._    
   
Enough for what? Once again, Hrant, you seem set to ignore the fact that hundreds of millions of people read hundreds of languages using the Latin script every day. The idea that the Latin script lacks sufficient visual clues simply is not supported by the most massive piece of evidence: the fact that it is read comfortably and efficiently by so many people.

All the academia aside, I dig unicase. But only because it adds variety to the palette of possibilities. I also dig Herbert Bayer's work (his originals, not the ITC Bauhaus revival).   
   
Stephen, your mention of unicase makes me want to put some in front of my four year old (kindergarten age). She knows her capitals, but can't recognize all her lowercase yet.   
   
\_\_\_   
   
By "the more variety the better" I'm referring to the variety that both cases (and the third quasi-case, unicase) adds to the collective design palette. I'm not really talking about long-running text. Which is why I'll get out of your (plural) way.
George Bush has got to stop taking money out of the American School system.
I'm not sure, Gerald. Were you insulting George Bush, the American school system or my daughter? I could choose to not be defensive on that but your tact is sorely lacking.

Hehehe. I hope he was just taking a random potshot at Bush   
which I admit to doing from time to time. Either way, it's off-topic.

I know. \*sigh\* Usually I can look the other way... I didn't mean to derail this thread. (I'm fully prepared, as the parent of my child, to take responsiblity for the quality of her education -- which is probably why I overreacted.)

\> Letters looking too much alike is not just a problem of the Roman alphabet.   
   
Certainly - I don't mean to single out the Roman alphabet, but it _is_ the world's main script, for the moment. Armenian has problems too (like an overly homogenous x-height region), but only [part of] 8 million people use it. Let's work on the big clumsy one first.   
   
\> Enough for what?   
   
I guess "enough" isn't a good qualifier - it's all relative, after all. Compared to Morse Code for example Latin is wondefully diverse. But compared to Hangul it's a village idiot.   
   
So my "enough" might mean "not as mush as it could". Why do you think dyslexia is much more common in Latin-using countries? It's pretty obvious for example that:   
1) Some groups of letters (like b/d/p/q, and h/n/u) are too similar.   
2) The vertical space is poorly used. Compare the descender and ascender space for example: the former has much richer shapes, but is used a lot less. All the ascenders except the "f" are sticks. And one of the letters (el) is just a stick by itself.   
   
The fact that laymen get along "just fine" and don't realize the problems means very little. That's a bit like saying we don't need airplanes.   
   
\> She knows her capitals, but can't recognize all her lowercase yet.   
   
A fine example of how _not_ to teach the alphabet...   
   
Yeah, let's first learn the letters that are used for 5% (or a lot less) of text, since the Romans were such fine people and all...

Apparently some type designer does not like trees. See vote, 2nd post.

Let's be realistic. If there were no "idiotic ads" in newspapers, there would be NO newspapers, and the same goes for magazines. Publishers don't crank this stuff out because they feel it their duty to keep us informed. It's money.   
   
Certainly we could remove most of the problem of paper waste if the publishers of material on glossy and clay coated paper would desist. I know the world would be a better place for it.   
   
In British Columbia it is now a very widespread practice to recycle paper (and all materials like metals and plastics that previously went into land fills). The clay-coated papers, that incidentally create bucks for graphic designers in the form of annual report work etc., dont recycle worth a damn.   
   
Decades ago when I worked on newspapers, there was a shift from 11 pica columns to 10 picas and 9 points. The reason was that they saved about 3/8" in width on every newspaper roll, and that translated to many tons of paper each year. The newspaper carried on skinnying up the columns ever couple of years by three points or so until they dailies were down to 10 pica columns. Eventually they furnished all of the Linotype machines with a more condensed typeface, and in a smaller size of 9 point rather than the previous 10 point. These apparently minimal measures saved the publisher lots of money in paper because the paper could order narrower rolls. I am certain their concern was with their bottom line rather than leaving a tree for a bobcat to climb.   
   
I have to say, as other have, that eliminating capital letters seems like an ineffective way to save paper . . . but who knows what if anything is going on in the brain box of any politican?
